Advisors: Izabela Stroe, Maqsood Mughal, Amhet Can Sabuncu, Cagdas Onal
Title: An Endoscopy Probe for Early Colorectal Cancer Detection
Abstract: Colonoscopies are routine procedures for many adults. For individuals with IBD these procedures are annual. Polyps or precancerous tissue is missed the most in this population as their inflamed bowels make it difficult to detect these regions. Cancerous tissue development is associated with increased conductivity as tight junction activity increases the flow of ions. We developed a coaxial probe to scan electrical properties of tissues, like conductance. The proposed design would be incorporated with current colonoscopes and fed through the working channel of these devices. Future studies will be required to test the device's ability to differentiate cancerous tissue.

Students: Jenna Currie, Thomas Lipkin, Dana Landry, Sarah Vasquez
Advisors: Pradeep Radhakrishnan, Dirk Albrecht, Kaveh Pahlavan
Title: Investigating the Use of Magnetic Actuation to Develop a Functional Tongue Prosthetic to Mimic Human Deglutition
Abstract: The goal of this project is to utilize magnetic actuation to create a functional tongue prosthetic for oral cancer patients. Glossectomy is a surgical procedure in which the tongue is removed mainly due to cancer and has affects on the eating and speaking of patients. Currently, tongue prosthetics are static and lack any functionality. Our project aimed to miniaturize the electrical components to fit within the oral cavity and move the prosthetic to aid with feeding. Magnetic actuation was explored and utilized as the method of movement.

Students: Samatha Grillo, Kalani Picho, Kenneth Rhodes, Alec Kneedler
Advisors: Marko Popovic, George Heineman, Gregory Fischer
Major: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
Title: Bio-Inspired Interactive Dino
Abstract: The goal of this MQP was to design, fabricate, and implement an interactive robot model of the head and neck of a Deinonychus that creates the impression of a living dinosaur. The neck contains 6 actuated degrees of freedom and is composed of custom-made vertebrae. The vertebral column is modelled and controlled as a continuum arm. The project makes use of Popovic Lab's Hydro Muscles, which are elastic linear actuators that replicate muscular motion. These Hydro Muscles are powered by a custom hydraulic system and control the dinosaur neck by pulling on wire 'tendons' that are attached to key points on the neck. The team focused on elements that mimicked anatomical structures in order to develop a system to mimic lifelike behavior.

Students: Ryan Carnemolla, Anirban Mukherjee, Amrit Parmanand, Emily Staknis
Title: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping with Atlas
Abstract: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is a powerful method for autonomously exploring new environments that had never been applied to humanoid robots. This project developed SLAM on the Atlas humanoid robot, allowing it to interact with and explore novel environments. The Atlas robot was programmed to create 3 dimensional maps of environments and localize itself within them. Due to constraints in time and safety the project was conducted mostly in simulation. Both stereo cameras and LiDar were used in experiments to identify the robot's surroundings and avoid obstacles. These sensors paired with the robot's locomotion allowed the Atlas robot to search and navigate unknown areas.

Students: Brian Wilkinson, Scott Rementer, Perla Wehbe
Title: Palm Print
Abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) has revolutionized the manufacturing world. It allows for the manufacturing of complex parts that would not normally be possible using traditional manufacturing methods. Since AM is a very cost effective and efficient way of manufacturing, it has become one of the most popular types of rapid prototyping. Rapid prototyping is very important during technical education because it allows students to work hands-on with their designs and learn more about designing for manufacturing. 3D printers can be very costly to purchase and are very difficult to move, after its initial set up. In this project, we look into a cost effective and compact 3D printer that can easily fit inside a student's backpack.

Advisors: Robert Krueger, Mustapha Fofana, Matthew Amissah
Title: Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems
Abstract: The Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems MQP provides a grinder to pulverize electronic waste in Agbogbloshie, a scrap yard in Ghana. Ghanaian expertise guided the project's focus on manufacturing and sustainable maintenance. SOLIDWORKS and ANSYS simulation tools were used to visualize and test the design. A steel prototype was assembled using the tools in Washburn Shops at WPI. Future revisions of the E-waste Recycling Grinder could scale a manufacturing plan and determine a grinder integration plan for Agbogbloshie.

Students: Yingbing Lu, Robert Batista,Sonia Litovchick, Lannan Jiang
Title: An Intuitive User Interface for Teleoperated Robotic Neuro-Intervention
Abstract: Interventional procedures navigate small instruments such as guidewires and catheters through the blood vessels under X-ray imaging guidance to treat diseases including ischemic heart disease and stroke. Interventional procedures can be performed remotely via robotic catheterization. The interventional devices are manipulated by a robot controlled remotely by the interventionalists. The team designed and prototyped a system that allows the interventionalists to perform the traditional over-the-wire technique and received haptic feedback during robotic catheterization. This intuitive user interface minimizes the learning curve in the clinical adoption of robotic catheterization and could enhance global healthcare service and equity.

Students: Rachel Arnold, Trevor Karrett, Chloe Melville
Title: Ischemic Stroke Detection
Abstract: Each year 795,000 Americans suffer from a stroke, 87% of them being ischemic where a blood clot travels from the heart to the brain causing irreparable damage. The potentially fatal consequences of these strokes could be avoided with early detection and removal of the clot. We developed phantom models of the neck and carotid artery for testing. Artificial blood and clots were pumped through the model, and an ultrasound probe connected to a computer running a computer vision algorithm was used to detect them. Our proof of concept shows that a wearable device could be created to preemptively detect ischemic strokes for at risk patients.

Students: Jack Chase, Tim Giddings, Ryan Johnson, Sabrina Cacapit, Sullivan Boyd, Kevin Boenisch, Nick Alescio, Jack Ruddat, Ben Steeves, Kyle France, Nathaniel Bajakian, Tobias Schaeffer, Julia Duffield, Trevor Ninesling, Clayton Besch, Anavat Siamwala, Noah Parker
Major: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
Title: Design and Optimization of an Electric FSAE Vehicle
Abstract: This project represents the efforts of 17 students across four majors to design WPI's first Formula SAE Electric race car. Formula SAE Electric is an engineering design competition where collegiate teams from around the world build electric race cars to compete in events on and off the track. The most challenging aspect of this competition is the endurance event, where many cars experience failure. To complete this event, we considered reliability and serviceability from the systems level all the way down to individual component design. This is the first of two years of development, so our prototypes will be passed on to next year's team to be finalized and face extensive testing before going to competition.
